content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/yuta/.config/claude/skills/speakerdeck

# SpeakerDeck Scraper

## Purpose

Download all slide images from a SpeakerDeck presentation URL. Zero dependencies ‚Äî uses only built-in fetch and fs APIs. The downloaded images can be read by Claude Vision or converted with `markitdown`.

## Run

```bash
BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude {baseDir}/scripts/speakerdeck.ts <speakerdeck-url> [-o output-dir]
```

### Arguments

| Arg | Description |
|-----|-------------|
| `<url>` | SpeakerDeck presentation URL (required) |
| `-o, --output <dir>` | Output directory (default: `$TMPDIR/speakerdeck-<id>/`) |

### Output (JSON to stdout)

```json
{
  "title": "Presentation Title",
  "presentationId": "abc123def456",
  "slideCount": 30,
  "outputDir": "/tmp/speakerdeck-abc123def456",
  "files": ["/tmp/speakerdeck-abc123def456/slide_000.jpg", "..."]
}
```

## Workflow Examples

### Read slides with Claude Vision

```bash
result=$(BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude {baseDir}/scripts/speakerdeck.ts "https://speakerdeck.com/user/talk")
# Then use the file paths from the JSON output with Read tool
```

### Convert to Markdown with markitdown

```bash
result=$(BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude {baseDir}/scripts/speakerdeck.ts "https://speakerdeck.com/user/talk")
dir=$(echo "$result" | jq -r '.outputDir')
for f in "$dir"/*.jpg; do markitdown "$f"; done
```

## How It Works

1. Fetches the SpeakerDeck page HTML to extract the presentation ID (from the player iframe URL)
2. Binary-search probes the CDN (`files.speakerdeck.com`) to determine slide count
3. Downloads all slide JPEGs (5 concurrent)

## Notes

- Images are 1920x1080 JPEG from SpeakerDeck's CDN
- Zero external dependencies ‚Äî runs with `BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude` (no bun/node install needed)
- Private or password-protected presentations are not supported

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/yuta/.config/claude/skills/defuddle

# Defuddle

Use Defuddle CLI to extract clean readable content from web pages. Prefer over WebFetch for standard web pages ‚Äî it removes navigation, ads, and clutter, reducing token usage.

If not installed: `npm install -g defuddle-cli`

## Usage

Always use `--md` for markdown output:

```bash
defuddle parse <url> --md
```

Save to file:

```bash
defuddle parse <url> --md -o content.md
```

Extract specific metadata:

```bash
defuddle parse <url> -p title
defuddle parse <url> -p description
defuddle parse <url> -p domain
```

## Output formats

| Flag | Format |
|------|--------|
| `--md` | Markdown (default choice) |
| `--json` | JSON with both HTML and markdown |
| (none) | HTML |
| `-p <name>` | Specific metadata property |


ARGUMENTS: https://efcl.info/2024/10/06/bun-single-file-executable-binary/

file.content:
---
name: speakerdeck
description: Download slide images from a SpeakerDeck presentation. Use when the user provides a SpeakerDeck URL and wants to read, summarize, or convert the slides.
user-invocable: true
---

# SpeakerDeck Scraper

## Purpose

Download all slide images from a SpeakerDeck presentation URL. Zero dependencies ‚Äî uses only built-in fetch and fs APIs. The downloaded images can be read by Claude Vision or converted with `markitdown`.

## Run

```bash
BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude {baseDir}/scripts/speakerdeck.ts <speakerdeck-url> [-o output-dir]
```

### Arguments

| Arg | Description |
|-----|-------------|
| `<url>` | SpeakerDeck presentation URL (required) |
| `-o, --output <dir>` | Output directory (default: `$TMPDIR/speakerdeck-<id>/`) |

### Output (JSON to stdout)

```json
{
  "title": "Presentation Title",
  "presentationId": "abc123def456",
  "slideCount": 30,
  "outputDir": "/tmp/speakerdeck-abc123def456",
  "files": ["/tmp/speakerdeck-abc123def456/slide_000.jpg", "..."]
}
```

## Workflow Examples

### Read slides with Claude Vision

```bash
result=$(BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude {baseDir}/scripts/speakerdeck.ts "https://speakerdeck.com/user/talk")
# Then use the file paths from the JSON output with Read tool
```

### Convert to Markdown with markitdown

```bash
result=$(BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude {baseDir}/scripts/speakerdeck.ts "https://speakerdeck.com/user/talk")
dir=$(echo "$result" | jq -r '.outputDir')
for f in "$dir"/*.jpg; do markitdown "$f"; done
```

## How It Works

1. Fetches the SpeakerDeck page HTML to extract the presentation ID (from the player iframe URL)
2. Binary-search probes the CDN (`files.speakerdeck.com`) to determine slide count
3. Downloads all slide JPEGs (5 concurrent)

## Notes

- Images are 1920x1080 JPEG from SpeakerDeck's CDN
- Zero external dependencies ‚Äî runs with `BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude` (no bun/node install needed)
- Private or password-protected presentations are not supported

1‚Üí---
     2‚Üíname: markitdown
     3‚Üídescription: Convert files (PDF, DOCX, PPTX, XLSX, HTML, images, audio, etc.) to Markdown using Microsoft's markitdown CLI. Use when the user wants to extract text content from documents, convert files for LLM processing, or read non-text file formats.
     4‚Üímetadata: {"openclaw":{"requires":{"bins":["markitdown"]}}}
     5‚Üíuser-invocable: true
     6‚Üí---
     7‚Üí
     8‚Üí# MarkItDown
     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí## Purpose
    11‚Üí
    12‚ÜíConvert a wide variety of file formats into Markdown text using Microsoft's [markitdown](https://github.com/microsoft/markitdown) CLI. Useful for extracting text from documents for LLM analysis, summarization, or ingestion into knowledge bases.
    13‚Üí
    14‚Üí## Supported Formats
    15‚Üí
    16‚Üí| Category | Formats |
    17‚Üí|----------|---------|
    18‚Üí| Documents | PDF, DOCX, PPTX, XLSX, XLS |
    19‚Üí| Web & Data | HTML, CSV, JSON, XML |
    20‚Üí| Media | Images (EXIF + OCR), Audio (metadata + transcription) |
    21‚Üí| eBooks | EPub |
    22‚Üí| Archives | ZIP (iterates over contents) |
    23‚Üí| Other | YouTube URLs, Outlook messages |
    24‚Üí
    25‚Üí## Basic Usage
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí```bash
    28‚Üí# Convert a file (output to stdout)
    29‚Üímarkitdown path/to/file.pdf
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí# Save output to a file
    32‚Üímarkitdown path/to/file.pdf -o output.md
    33‚Üí
    34‚Üí# Pipe from stdin
    35‚Üícat path/to/file.pdf | markitdown
    36‚Üí```
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí## Options
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí| Flag | Description |
    41‚Üí|------|-------------|
    42‚Üí| `-o <file>` | Write output to a file instead of stdout |
    43‚Üí| `-d` | Use Azure Document Intelligence for conversion |
    44‚Üí| `-e "<endpoint>"` | Azure Document Intelligence endpoint URL |
    45‚Üí| `--use-plugins` | Enable third-party plugins |
    46‚Üí| `--list-plugins` | Show installed plugins |
    47‚Üí
    48‚Üí## Workflow
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí### Single File Conversion
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí```bash
    53‚Üí# Convert and capture the result
    54‚Üíresult=$(markitdown document.pdf)
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí# Convert and save
    57‚Üímarkitdown document.pdf -o document.md
    58‚Üí```
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí### Batch Conversion
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí```bash
    63‚Üí# Convert all PDFs in a directory
    64‚Üífor f in *.pdf; do
    65‚Üí  markitdown "$f" -o "${f%.pdf}.md"
    66‚Üídone
    67‚Üí```
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí### Pipe into Other Tools
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí```bash
    72‚Üí# Convert and count words
    73‚Üímarkitdown document.pdf | wc -w
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí# Convert and search for a term
    76‚Üímarkitdown document.pdf | grep -i "search term"
    77‚Üí```
    78‚Üí
    79‚Üí## Agent Usage Notes
    80‚Üí
    81‚Üí- Output goes to stdout by default. Capture it in a variable or redirect to a file.
    82‚Üí- For large files, prefer saving to a file with `-o` rather than capturing stdout.
    83‚Üí- Image conversion extracts EXIF metadata and OCR text. For richer image descriptions, use the Python API with an LLM client instead.
    84‚Üí- ZIP files are automatically extracted and each contained file is converted.
    85‚Üí- If conversion fails for a format, check that the corresponding optional dependency is installed (e.g., `markitdown[pdf]` for PDF support).
    86‚Üí

content.thinking:
The speakerdeck script is a local file (not from GitHub), so I can't use `fetchFromGitHub`. It uses only built-in Node/Bun APIs (fetch, fs, path, os, util), so it has zero npm dependencies.

For a Bun single-file executable, I need to:
1. Use `bun build --compile` to create a standalone binary
2. Package it as a Nix derivation

Since this is a local source file with zero dependencies, I can use a simple `stdenv.mkDerivation` that:
1. Takes the local source
2. Uses bun to compile it


3. Installs the resulting binary

The user wants to use nixpkgs for now, so I'll leverage bun from there to build. The script uses `Bun.argv.slice(2)` for command-line arguments, which will continue working fine when compiled into a standalone binary. I'll create an overlay file to define this custom derivation.

Now I need to check if bun is available in nixpkgs and set up the overlay to use `bun build --compile` during the build phase, referencing the local TypeScript source.

---
name: speakerdeck
description: Download slide images from a SpeakerDeck presentation. Use when the user provides a SpeakerDeck URL and wants to read, summarize, or convert the slides.
user-invocable: true
---

# SpeakerDeck Scraper

## Purpose

Download all slide images from a SpeakerDeck presentation URL. Zero dependencies ‚Äî uses only built-in fetch and fs APIs. The downloaded images can be read by Claude Vision or converted with `markitdown`.

## Run

```bash
BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude {baseDir}/scripts/speakerdeck.ts <speakerdeck-url> [-o output-dir]
```

### Arguments

| Arg | Description |
|-----|-------------|
| `<url>` | SpeakerDeck presentation URL (required) |
| `-o, --output <dir>` | Output directory (default: `$TMPDIR/speakerdeck-<id>/`) |

### Output (JSON to stdout)

```json
{
  "title": "Presentation Title",
  "presentationId": "abc123def456",
  "slideCount": 30,
  "outputDir": "/tmp/speakerdeck-abc123def456",
  "files": ["/tmp/speakerdeck-abc123def456/slide_000.jpg", "..."]
}
```

## Workflow Examples

### Read slides with Claude Vision

```bash
result=$(BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude {baseDir}/scripts/speakerdeck.ts "https://speakerdeck.com/user/talk")
# Then use the file paths from the JSON output with Read tool
```

### Convert to Markdown with markitdown

```bash
result=$(BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude {baseDir}/scripts/speakerdeck.ts "https://speakerdeck.com/user/talk")
dir=$(echo "$result" | jq -r '.outputDir')
for f in "$dir"/*.jpg; do markitdown "$f"; done
```

## How It Works

1. Fetches the SpeakerDeck page HTML to extract the presentation ID (from the player iframe URL)
2. Binary-search probes the CDN (`files.speakerdeck.com`) to determine slide count
3. Downloads all slide JPEGs (5 concurrent)

## Notes

- Images are 1920x1080 JPEG from SpeakerDeck's CDN
- Zero external dependencies ‚Äî runs with `BUN_BE_BUN=1 claude` (no bun/node install needed)
- Private or password-protected presentations are not supported

The user is asking about the system/platform concern - the compiled binary is a Mach-O arm64 binary, so it would only work on macOS ARM. If this is in a dotfiles repo used on NixOS (x86_64-linux) as well, the binary wouldn't work there.

Let me check what systems are configured in this repo.
